They fulfill all the requirements of their family with the income from selling vegetables. Ruwa and her husband have three children: two daughters and one son. Their daughters are studying in grades 7 and 6 and their son is studying in grade 2.

loans.use: to buy vegetables for her business

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Mabinty. She is married to a contractor, and has 3 children, ages 14, 11 and 3 years all going to school. 

In 2000, Mabinty established her textiles and rubber slippers business. She began her business after she left school when she got in an accident. She did not have anyone to help her further her education. She decided to join her aunt in business. It is the only thing she can earn money for and it is one thing she knows best. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,049,000 SLL every month from this business. She is only assisted by a family member. Her suppliers are located in Conakry and Freetown. She usually travels to Conakry twice a month and to Freetown whenever she has shortages in stock.

She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Mabinty has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase 1 bale of English Wax Cotton @ 5,000,000 SLL. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 263,000 SLL. The loans will help her greatly if she is given the chance to access them.

In the future, Mabinty plans to open a larger outlet with different types of textiles and footwear. It is good because it will help her make a positive turn in her business. She is very excited with her business. She wants to educate her children to a higher standard. Mabinty's major challenges are the rainy season and inflation in foreign currency, but she goes for quality products with prices that can be afforded by her customers. Mabinty uses part of her profit to add onto her operating capital and the rest she sets aside for any domestic problems. She is hardworking and honest. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase 1 bale of English Wax Cotton @ 5,000,000 SLL

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: Isatu, a 38-year-old mother of three children ranging in age from 12 to 19, two of whom are in school, lives in West Point, Liberia. Since 2000, Isatu has been selling fashion clothing, having started her business through friends.  Now requesting a loan to purchase more clothes (blouses, jeans, trousers) for her business, she plans to expand her enterprise to help her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fashion clothes (blouses, jeans, trousers) for her business.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Fatmata. She is married to a trader and has four children, aged 25, 18,15 and 10 years respectively; all are school-going children. She has one additional dependent, who lives with her because she is a foster child.   

In 1991, Fatmata established her cola-nuts, palm oil, pepper and groundnut business. She began her business because she was unprivileged to attend school and her father forced her into early marriage at the age of 15 years to a businessman. They did business together for some years but later her husband gave her some money to establish her own business, which has grown over the years from a stall to a shop.  

Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 1,066,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000.   

Fatmata has already received and successfully repaid four loans, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase the following items: Cola-nuts - 10 bags @ Le400,00; and palm oil - 8 rubbers @ Le90,000. The balance will be used to pay laborers.  

She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 160,000. In the future, Fatmata plans to build another house and have her own store. She also plans to provide a quality education for her children.  

She feels good in taking this loan as it will help her to earn more income. Her major challenge is that sometimes she can buy some items with a high cost from her suppliers but when she goes to sell them, there will be a fall in prices. Competition is high, but she overcomes her competitors by selling at a reduced cost. She serves 10 customers each day.   

Her business is popular because she is honest and sells at a reduce price. Her suppliers are located in Bo Town and Sanda. She transports her supplies by public vehicle, and she buys three times per month. She adds her profit to the business. She is planning to expand her business and this will be accomplished by acquiring loans. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase the following items: cola-nuts - 10 bags @ Le400,00; and palm oil - 8 rubbers @ Le90,000.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 33-year-old married man from Gaza. He lives with his wife and three children. Ahmad owns his own small farm where he raises chickens. 

Ahmad is requesting a loan to buy more chickens for his farm. This will increase his income and allow him to sell more chickens.

loans.use: buy chickens

loans.name: Tessito Gadamayo / Wakilare Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Wakilaré  est crée en Décembre 2007. Il  est composé de 17 femmes qui  habitent le même quartier. Elles ont une bonne entente. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame D.(assise à l’extrême droit sur la photo) est responsable du groupe. Elle est  âgée de 47 ans. 
Elle est mariée et mère de sept enfants. 

Durant ce cycle elle voudrait mieux développer son activité de vente de tissu. Une activité qu'elle mène depuis plus de six ans. Comme activité parallèle elle fait la vente de légumes dans le marché de son quartier.

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de s'approvisionner en grande quantité en tissus pour la revente.

Les bénéfices générés par son activité lui permettront d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la scolarité et de la nourriture des enfants.
texts.en:
The Wakilaré group was created in December 2007. It is made up of 17 women who all live in the same district and all get along well together. The women are all small retailers.

D., the woman sitting on the far right of the picture, is the group´s leader. She is 47 years old, married and the mother of 7 children. She has been selling fabrics for over 6 years, and would like to develop that side of her business. She also sells vegetables at her local market.

This loan will enable D. to buy large amounts of fabric for resale. The profits from her business will allow her to support her husband with the children's educational and food expenses.

loans.use: to buy fabric for resale.

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en:
Warlito has been working his one hectare of rice fields since 1988.  He is grateful because it has been 23 years of patience and sacrifice he has made to earn a living.  He is married and has three children.  One of the things he appreciates most is his wife being supportive in his all decisions.  His wife has been raising animals for fattening within their local community.

Warlito would like to educate all his children because he doesn't want them to suffer what he has already gone through.  So, he is aiming to improve his rice production so that he can gain a plentiful harvest every crop season.  He has tried his best to budget his profits but due to the abrupt increase in the price of basic commodities he can no longer afford to purchase some farm inputs.  In this situation, he is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000.  This amount will serve as his hope in achieving his plans to improve his farming techniques, which will enable him to earn a greater income.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs for his rice farming business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 66 years old. He is married to Lucia and they have two children. For the past eight years, he has been in the livestock sales business in Olkalau town. John was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing client and this will be his first loan.  

John is requesting a loan to buy sheep to raise and sell and later to buy a dairy cow. In the future, he hopes to purchase more dairy cows and sustain his milk production business.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Silvino

texts.es:
Silvino tiene 30 años de edad, vive en pareja con Gricelda, tienen 1 hijo y viven en su casa de la ciudad de Carapeguá.
Silvino se dedica al macate hace mas de 6 años, llevando sus productos de artesanía como la hamaca, la frazada poybi y otros productos a la capital del país. Tiene una moto para trasladarse tranquila y cómodamente para la venta de sus productos.
Su esposa se dedica a la artesanía fabricando sus propios productos que luego él lleva a vender. Afirma que los mismos son de muy buena calidad. Son parte de una familia muy trabajadora ya que su padre se dedica al mismo rubro, fue el  que le enseñó que debe trabajar para así poder darle a su familia techo, alimentación, educación, etc.
Silvino solicita el préstamo para la compra de materias primas como  Hilos, tintes de color y demás insumos para elaboración de las hamacas y frazadas que vende.
texts.en:
Silvino is 30 years old.  He lives in Carapeguá with his wife, Gricelda and they have one child.
Silvino has worked as a street vendor for 6 years.  He makes hammocks, Aho Po´I (fine material) blankets, and other artisanal items.  He takes his products to the market in the country’s capital, transporting them quietly and comfortably on his motorbike
His wife makes her own artisanal products and sells them as well.  He asserts that their products are of good quality.  They are part of a hard-working family as his father works in the same trade.  It was his father that taught him that he must work in order to provide his family with a roof over their heads, food, and an education.
Silvino is requesting this loan to buy raw materials such as thread, colored dyes, and other supplies for the creation of the hammocks and blankets that he sells.

loans.use: to buy thread, dyes, and other materials for the creation of hammocks and blankets.

loans.name: Nabieu

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Nabieu. He is married and his spouse assists him in the business. He has three children, aged 21, 16 and 10 years; only two are school-going children. 

In 1987, Nabieu established his business selling shoes, school/traveling bags, electrical appliances, tools, slippers, sandals, door locks, etc. He began his business because his father was a farmer and he was introduced to farming at an early age. He didn't go to school. After farming with his father for some years, he decided to farm on his own. He grew peppers in two farming seasons and he sold the harvest he got, then bought slippers and started selling in the village.  

After some months, he started moving to nearby villages. The business has grown from peddling to a shop. Working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, he earns about 2,310,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Nabieu has already received and successfully repaid two loans, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase shoes - 2 cartons @ L840,000; traveling bags - 50 pieces @ Le35,000; sandals - 15 dozen @ Le96,000; door locks - 20 pieces @ Le10,000; and slippers - 1 carton @ Le400,000.  The balance of Le30,000 will be used to pay laborers. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 431,063. 

In the future, Nabieu plans to build another house and educate his children to the university level. He also plans to improve the standard of living of his family. He is happy about the loan, and this will help him to increase his income. His major challenge is the fluctuation in foreign currency, which sometimes affects the cost of items and transportation. Competition is high but he is different from his competitors because he sells different items. He can serves 15 customers each day. His business is popular because he sells quality items and his shop is general merchandise. He is assisted by his wife.  

His suppliers are in Guinea-Conakry; he transports his items by public vehicle and he buys three times in a month. He plows the profit back into the business. He is planning to expand his business, and this will be achieved by managing the business well. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase shoes - 2 cartons @ Le 840,000; traveling bags - 50 pieces @ Le 35,000; sandals - 15 dozen @ Le 96,000; door locks - 20 pieces @ Le 10,000; and slippers - 1 carton @ Le 400,000.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia is 44 years old and married with a family of seven. She supports five children who are in school. For the past 13 years, Teresia has run a cereal store as well as a small general merchandise kiosk. She earns an average profit of 20,000 KES and has been able to meet the financial needs of her family.
  
Teresia is requesting an 80,000 KES loan to purchase stock for her store including beans, green grams, and rice, and to pay to transport these goods. She has repaid three previous loans. With the income from her loan, Teresia intends to expand her business by increasing the number of items she sells. Her dream is to buy a plot of land and build a house for her family and also houses to rent out.

loans.use: to purchase cereals

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis said that,"Patience and hard work" are the key to become a successful entrepreneur.

Luis is married and has two school-aged children. His wife is an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker), while he is in charge of taking care of his rice fields and children.  Luis' goal's push him to face challenges in life.  Nowadays, he is suffering from a shortage of funds because of his family household expenses and needs of his children. He decided to borrow additional capital of PHP30,000, allowing him to buy farm supplies to improve his rice fields. He believes that he can increase his rice production this coming crop season and save for the future of his children.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies needed in improving rice production

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac has operated his timber sales business in Olkalau town for the last three years. He is 39 years old, married to Esther, and they have three school going children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy old trees and cut them into timber for sale and also for labor purposes.

In the future, Isaac hopes to acquire a lorry and offer transportation services and make more income, thereby improving the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy old trees and cut them into timber for sale and also for labor purposes.

loans.name: Tessito Gadamayo/nafore Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Naforé est créé le 15 Novembre 2006 au jour d’inauguration du banc villageois. Il est composé de 19 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier. Les membres ont des liens de parenté. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Fatou (assise à l’extrême droite) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 49 ans. Elle est mariée et  mère de quatre enfants, elle prend en charge aussi deux de ses neveux. 

Elle vend des fruits et légumes, de l’huile de palme et du miel dans le marché de son quartier. Elle a  une bonne expérience dans ce domaine pour l’avoir pratiqué pendant environs dix ans.

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra  spécifiquement d’acheter du miel pour la revente.

Elle désire soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge sanitaire et alimentaire de la famille, de même elle compte constituer une épargne pour de futurs investissements.
texts.en:
Group Naforé was created on November 15, 2006, on the day of the inauguration of the "banc villageois" (village lending association). It is composed of 19 women, all coming from the same district. The members are all related. Their main business is retail.

Mrs. Fatou (sitting all the way to the right) is the group's leader. She is 49 years old. She is married and a mother of four. She also has two of her nephews in her care.

She sells fruits and vegetables, palm oil and honey at her local market. She has a lot of experience in this business, since she has been active in it for about ten years.

Specifically, her new loan will enable her to purchase honey for retail.

She wishes to support her husband in providing for the family's needs in terms of health and food. In addition, she is planning on creating savings for future investments.

loans.use: to buy honey for resale.

loans.name: Alie

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Alie.  He is married to a trader, and has five children aged 15, 10, 8, 6 and 3 years, three are school going children. In 2001, Alie established his pot making business. He began his business because he went into blacksmith work when he lost his father at the age of 16 years and there was nobody to support his education.  His mother was a housewife and since there was no money to support his schooling, she sent him to a blacksmith workshop to be trained in making pots.  Now he is a specialist in making pots.  Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about Le 2,140,875 every month from this business.  

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000.  Alie has already received and successfully repaid one loan and now requires a new loan in order to produce the following - 8 big sets of pots, 5 medium sets of pots, and 7 small sets of pots. The balance Le 30,000 will be used to transport the raw materials.  

He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 2,140,88. In the future, Alie plans to acquire his own workshop and educate his children to the university level which he was able to do himself.  His major problem is that sometimes he can make a pot and missed the dimensions that will lead to him having to redo it to get the correct quality. He serves about 15 customers each day, his business is popular because he is the only pot maker around that locality.  He has three trainees in his workshop.  He gets his raw materials from Freetown and Makeni Township.  He usually transports his materials by public transport. He plows back the profit into the business. 

He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to produce new pots at his blacksmith shop and transport the raw materials
